channel.title: maGaming RSS Feed - thesixthaxis_com
channel.description: A cleaned-up version of the original gaming feed for thesixthaxis_com

item.title: Something for the Weekend – 08/11/25
item.content:encoded:
The travails of Grand Theft Auto 6 really are a sign of just how much game development has changed over the decades. There were three GTAs on PS2, there were two on PS3, and now we’re lucky to see one big game a generation from Rockstar – I think we ought to really count Red Dead Redemption 2 in this. It’s something that’s echoed by the likes of Naughty Dog, where the most prestigious studios now take what feels like forever to produce their games.

Anyway, I’m talking about that because GTA 6 got delayed by another six months.

In the News This Week

So, that’s obviously the biggest headline of the week, closely followed by the back and forth over work unionisation at Rockstar. Let’s get to those and all the other biggest stories we’ve caught.

  • GTA 6 has been delayed again to November 2026
  • Rockstar responds to union busting accusations, says fired employees were leakers
  • Marvel 1943: Rise of Hydra has now been delayed beyond early 2026
  • Square Enix announces staff redundancies alongside increased use of AI
  • Dead By Daylight 2v8 mode is getting a Silent Hill x Castlevania crossover
  • Steam Deck can now download on the down low with new display-off mode
  • PlayStation Portal gets full PS Plus cloud streaming, and you can even stream your own games
  • ’83 Early Access has been pushed back to 2026
  • The Fortnite X Simpsons crossover has been a pretty big hit
  • Battlefield 6’s challenges just got a lot easier to do
  • The end of Halo Infinite content is here with Operation: Infinite

Games in Review & Featured Articles

It was a middling week for our reviews this week, unless you’re into a bit of musou.

  • Hyrule Warriors: Age of Imprisonment – NSW2 – 8/10
  • Football Manager 26 – PS5, XSX|S, PC, Mac – 6/10
  • Hotel Barcelona – PS5, XSX|S, PC – 6/10
  • Rise of Industry 2 – PS5, XSX|S, PC – 6/10
  • Painkiller – PS5, XSX|S, PC – 5/10
  • Biped 2 – PS5, XSX|S, PS4, PC – 4/10

Then we had reviews of the Boulies Master Series 2025 gaming chair, and the Turtle Beach Racer Wireless Wheel, which you can pop onto your lap for some race time.

Beyond that, Dom spoke to the cast behind the ambitious FMV revival of AKIBA Lost, and I got another hands on session with Kirby Air Riders ahead of this weekend’s multiplayer test

Rounding out the week, What We Played featured Arc Raiders, Ghost of Yotei and Hyrule Warriors: Age of Imprisonment.

Trailer Park

Metroid Prime 4: Beyond has got a new trailer

Kiborg dev announces party game Chicken Chicken

The PEAK ROOTS update is here

Your Achievements

What have you been playing this week?

  • TSBonyman told us tales of Conquistadorio and Thimbleweed Park, the former having more of a Machinarium tone, and the latter being akin to a classic LucasArts point and clicker.

That’s the round up for this week’s round up. Enjoy the weekend, and we’ll catch you for more gaming shenanigans next week!



https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2025/11/08/something-for-the-weekend-08-11-25/

item.title: The end of Halo Infinite content is here with Operation: Infinite
item.content:encoded:
Halo Studios has announced that Halo Infinite has reached the end of the road as a live service, with Operation: Infinite set to be the last major content update when it arrives on 18th November.

The team writes, “As we look back on four years of evolution and updates in Halo Infinite, we’d like to thank our community for your steadfast support. Without your feedback and enthusiasm, Halo Infinite multiplayer would not be the special place it is today: a robust arena for slaying and playing, with something for every Spartan.

“With multiple Halo titles in development, we’ll need our whole team’s combined focus to deliver new experiences with the same passion and care that our community has given us. While we remain committed to supporting Halo Infinite on the road ahead, Operation: Infinite is the last major content update currently planned.”

This final content update will bring a 2X boosts to Career Rank and SP, a 100-tier Operation Pass, eight armour sets to earn, new Ranked Seasons, and 200 new customisations in The Exchange.

Following this, the game will still be receiving stability updates, and Halo Studios will continue to support it with rotating in-game challenges to let you progress through the Operation Passes that will remain available, and there will be new ranked rewards, ranked seasons and community events. There just won’t be any more big content drops and battle passes.

This is in large part down to Halo Studios needing to put more resources toward their upcoming projects. A lot is being made of the studio’s old plan for Halo Infinite to be a 10-year game, but that plan was made at a very different time with different studio leadership, and grand aspirations for the Xbox Series X|S generation. But Halo Infinite then suffered a difficult launch, the Xbox Series has struggled, and Microsoft has dramatically changed its plans. For Halo, the studio has jumped across to developing in Unreal Engine 5, it’s rebranded from 343 Industries to Halo Studios, and Halo: Campaign Evolved has been announced – a remake of the first game in UE5 that’s coming to PS5, Xbox Series and PC. There’s also another mooted live service game rumoured to be in the works.

I enjoyed Halo Infinite through its first year or so, but it’s actually a little bit surprising that the studio stuck it out this long.

Source: Halo Waypoint



https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2025/11/08/the-end-of-halo-infinite-content-is-here-with-operation-infinite/
